title-group.article-title: Experimental validation of a shape memory alloy retrofitting application

article-meta.aff: 1Department of Structural Mechanics, University of Pavia, Italy

author-notes.corresp: R AlSaleh, Department of Structural Mechanics, University of Pavia, via Ferrata 1, 27100 Pavia, Italy Email: raed.alsaleh@unipv.it

permissions.copyright-statement: © The Author(s) 2011 Reprints and permissions: sagepub.co.uk/journalsPermissions.nav

abstract.p: Minarets are spread across urban nuclei. Their structural weakness could result in failures with heavy consequences. However, the retrofit solutions are limited due to their simple cantilever scheme. The use of metallic pre-stressed wires/cables is a rather consolidated technique. The use of shape memory alloy (SMA) wires has been recently investigated. In view of such an application, a series of reduced-scale tests was planned and realized. This paper synthesizes the full report on an experimental work performed to study the effect of SMA wires on the dynamic behavior of a single degree of freedom model built in laboratory to represent a 1/16th of a minaret actually built in Cairo, Egypt. The model was tested under free vibration for different values of the axial force, before and after adding SMA wires. The results showed enhancements in the stiffness when the SMA wires were added and when the axial force increased, while a decrease in damping ratios was detected when increasing the applied axial force or after providing SMA wires.

sec.title: 1. Introduction
sec.p: Minarets are all around Islamic religious centers, that is, in the middle of old urban nuclei as well as new residential areas. Owing to their simple structural conception (the minaret is just a vertical cantilever), they are often complicated by changes along the height in the section geometry and material density. Structural problems occurring during their lifetime are sometimes solved by their full replacement. Indeed, the consequence of a failure (Casciati and AlSaleh, 2009; Casciati and Faravelli, 2010) can be serious, resulting in lost human lives and damages to the surrounding properties.

The attempted retrofit solutions span from base isolation in El-Attar et al. (2004), to energy dissipation by dampers in Bennati et al. (2005), from adding an internal (steel) skeleton in Ballio (1993), to tensioning by external metallic cables in Castellano et al. (1999). Actually the last reference has already introduced the adoption of shape memory alloy (SMA) wires, in Nickel-Titanium. A recently ended research project funded by the European Union (Casciati and Van der Eijk, 2008) identified the adoption of a Cu-based alloy as the basis for an effective sustainable and cost-effective retrofit technology for non-invasive rehabilitation of massive limestone/masonry structures. Targeted laboratory tests were carried out by Casciati and Hamdaoui (2008), and an application to a real structural system is reported by Chrysostomou et al. (2008). See also Gentile and Saisi (2007) for the structure identification and damage assessment process.

In view of an application to the retrofit of minarets, El-Attar et al. (2008) introduced a model to be tested. It was assumed to represent a 1/16th scale of the actual Qusun minaret in Cairo, Egypt (Figure 1). The Qusun minaret is one of the Mamluk era minarets that were constructed in the 14th century. It is currently separated from any surrounding building and is directly resting on the ground. Field investigations were conducted to obtain several characteristics of the minaret, and then ambient vibration tests were performed to determine its modal parameters (i.e. natural frequencies and mode shapes). The Qusun minaret was constructed by the prince Seif Eldin Qusun Al-Saki for teaching Islamic rules, and it is located now in Al-Suyuti cemetery. It has a rectangular stone shaft carrying an octagonal second story with a stone Mabkharah on top. The total height of the minaret is 40.02 m, with the first balcony at 16.80 m from the ground level, the second balcony at 24.40 m, and the third one at 31.85 m. The base rectangular shaft is about 5.42 m × 5.42 m and it extends to the first balcony. A survey study was conducted to determine the minaret cross-sections and wall thicknesses along its height, and the results are presented in Figure 1. An examination of the minaret walls indicated that the minaret body is constructed of two layers of flat-faced limestone blocks, each layer composed of blocks of different dimensions connected together by mortar. A filling material consisting of cohesive and cohesionless materials, highly chaotic with limestone, is placed between the external and the internal layers. Starting from the second balcony up to the top level, a single layer of limestone blocks is used. The material properties of the minaret limestone and the filling material are listed Table 1. Figure 1.
Qusun minaret and it geometrical properties (dimensions are in meters). Table 1.
The minaret materials’ properties
Property Limestone Filling
Elastic modulus (MPa) 3350 50
Specific gravity (kN/m3) 21.72 20.0
Poisson’s ratio 0.20 0.20
Compressive strength (MPa) 14.74 NA
Tensile strength (MPa) 1.34 NA
NA: not available.

The complicated shape of the real minaret was simplified in the laboratory into a cantilever-type model (single degree of freedom [SDOF]) that faithfully reflects the main aspects of the minaret conditions regarding: (a) geometry; (b) stress level; and (c) dynamic response. The experimental model was then utilized to perform an experimental work aimed mainly at investigating the effect of adding SMA wires to the SDOF system. A series of free vibration tests was conducted on this model before and after adding the SMA wires. The sensitivity to variations in the axial load upon the system is also investigated (El-Habbal, 2008). This paper provides a full report on the results of the experimental tests carried out.

sec.title: 2.1. The model
sec.p:
A simplified SDOF system was constructed in the laboratory, which consisted mainly of a mass supported vertically by a cantilever masonry column, as shown in Figure 2. Figure 2.
The experimental model setup (dimensions are in centimeters).

In developing the experimental model, the target was to construct a 1/16th scale model of the Qusun minaret. The similitude requirements needed in achieving this purpose are listed in Table 2. Table 2.
Implemented similitude parameters
Scaling parameter Experimental model Qusun minaret Scale
Length Le Lm Lm/Le = 16
Time Te Tm Tm/Te = 4
Frequency Fe fm Fm/fe = 0.25
Gravity Ge Gm Neglected
Acceleration Ae Am Am/Ae = 1.0
Mass density Me Mm Mm/Me = 0.0625
Strain Se Sm Sm/Se = 1
Stress Ste Stm Stm/Ste = 1
Young’s modulus Ye Ym Ym/Ye = 1
Specific stiffness SSe SSm SSm/SSe = 16
Force Fe Fm Fm/Fe = 256
Displacement De Dm Dm/De = 16
Energy Ee Em Em/Ee = 4096

The model shown in Figure 2 consists of a reinforced concrete base firmly connected to the rigid floor by means of four steel anchors of 45 mm diameter. It has a square base of scale 1.5 m and the height is 0.5 m. The concrete base supports a limestone hollow-square column with outer width of 40 cm and inner width of 20 cm. The clear height of the column is 2 m. 10 cm × 10 cm × 20 cm limestone bricks were used in the column construction. Brick rows were glued together by Portland cement mortar with a cement to sand ratio of 1:3. On the top of this column a lumped mass that simulates the SDOF system is placed; it is a reinforced concrete block with dimensions of 1.2 m × 1.2 m × 0.75 m and total of weight of 25 kN. A 30 mm diameter steel rod was fixed at the center of the concrete base, passing through the hollow column up to the top level of the concrete block to be utilized as a pre-stressing bar, in order to vary the applied vertical load upon the system.

The model was designed and constructed inside the Concrete Research Laboratory in the University of Cairo. The concrete mix used to cast both the base and the top block was with minimum compressive cubic strength of 25 MPa, as measured seven days after casting. The concrete mix contained the following proportions: 1:2.75:1.5:0.475 of cement, coarse aggregate, fine aggregate, and water, respectively. Grade 36 steel bars were used in the concrete reinforcement. Limestone bricks with dimensions 10 cm × 10 cm × 20 cm were used to construct the hollow-square section limestone column. Four steel wires of 4 mm nominal diameter were fixed on the base and the top blocks to be used to connect four SMA bars between the two concrete blocks. The SMA bars were 3.5 mm nominal diameter and 60 cm length. They were provided by the University of Pavia from the same stock used in Casciati and Hamdaoui (2008).

sec.title: 2.2. Test specifications
sec.p: The testing schedule was divided into two steps; the first stage investigates the overall behavior of the reference specimen under free vibration, while in the second stage the specimen was equipped with the SMA wires after all the tests of the first stage, and the same free vibration tests were repeated on the retrofitted specimen in a reversed order in terms of the external applied axial force.

For each step, three sets of free vibration testing were carried out, varying the applied vertical load through three values: 25, 75, and 125 kN. From the first value (directly induced by the mass) one jumps to the others through a hydraulic jack subjected on the central pre-stressing bar, and monitored by a 100 kN capacity load cell. The overall structural behavior under free vibration was recorded in the two perpendicular plan directions x and y, the bending plans being first (x, z) and then (y, z).

Free vibration was induced in the specimen by applying a gradually increased horizontal displacement on the top point of the concrete block until the required initial displacement is obtained. This step was repeated four times with different initial displacement values (1, 2, 3, and 5 mm) for each value of vertical loading. The applied initial displacement was monitored by means of one LVDT (linear variable differential transducer).

In the second stage of the test, the SMA bars were initially strained to 1% as an initial strain after being subjected to the specimen. The used SMA bar device was previously tested in the WIND-CHIME (Wide Range Non-INtrusive Devices toward Conservation of HIstorical Monuments in the MEditerranean Area) European project.

The results of each test were recorded for one minute with sampling rate of 200 p.p.s. (points per second), using three tri-axial force balanced accelerometers produced by Kinemetrics with ±0.25 g range. The accelerometers were connected, through dedicated cables, to a 16-channel signal conditioning unit, type Kinemetrics VSS-3000; which in turn was connected to a laptop computer equipped with a high-speed ‘input/output (I/O) Tech’ data acquisition card.

sec.title: 2.3. Summary of the available signals
sec.p:
Table 3 summarizes the parameters that characterize each test. There are four attributes, with 4, 3, 2, and 2 specifications, respectively. They result in 48 different tests, that is, set of signals. The sequence of obtaining these signals (namely, performing the corresponding test) is clarified in Table 4, where the signal label summarizes the parameters applied in that test; for example, in the case of signal (1-0-X-C): 1 means 1 mm of initial displacement, 0 is the value in tons for the extra applied axial force, X is the direction of excitation, and the last character distinguishes between control specimens (C) and specimens equipped with SMA wires (S). It must be clarified that only a few signals were fully reliable in the intermediate step characterized by 5 tons of extra load. This is why the focus in this paper is on the 0 and 10-ton specifications.

For each considered test, the response of the specimen to the free vibration in the three directions (x, y, and z) was measured by the three accelerometers. Figures 3 and 4 show a sample response in two directions (x and y) for the same case of initial displacement and axial load, but without the SMA wires in Figure 3 and with the SMA wires in Figure 4, acquired by the three accelerometers (A, B, and C). The figures prove a lower response in the magnitude value of acceleration in the signals obtained after adding the SMA wires. The differences are clearer in the transversal direction of excitation (i.e. along the y-direction in this case). This is because the maximum value in the direction of excitation is controlled by the provided initial value of displacement, which is the same in both cases before and after adding the SMA wires. Figure 3.
Time history for 2-0-X-C measured by three accelerometers (A, B, and C): (a) response along the x-direction; (b) response along the y-direction. Figure 4.
Time history for 2-0-X-S measured by three accelerometers (A, B, and C): (a) response along the x-direction; (b) response along the y-direction.
Three remarks should be added.

list-item.p: For most of the tests, the signals of the three accelerograms are quite consistent with each other, so any of them can be used in the following elaborations. However, in some cases one of the signals is not consistent (while the remaining two are consistent with each other) and is disregarded.

The signals in Figures 3 and 4 were processed by a band pass filtering in the range 0.6–20 Hz; an example of unprocessed signal is given in Figure 5. Figure 5.
Unfiltered signal of 2-0-X-S measured by three accelerometers (A, B, and C): (a) response along the x-direction; (b) response along the y-direction.

Not all the signals have the regular shape shown in Figures 3 and 4. Figures 6 and 7 report some unexpected responses. In Figure 6, associated with 0 ton, 5 mm displacement and with the SMA wires installed, there is a jump of intensity. In Figure 7 (10 ton, 1 mm and without SMA wires) there are changes in the decay trend. Figure 6.
Time histories for 5-0-X-S measured by three accelerometers (A, B, and C). Figure 7.
Time histories for 1-10-Y-C measured by three accelerometers (A, B, and C).

sec.title: 3.1. Tests without SMA wires
sec.p:
The frequency analysis of the signals was developed after the band pass filtering in the range of 0.6–20 Hz. The frequency contents of the signals sequenced in Table 4 from 17 to 20 (extra load of 100 kN) are plotted in Figure 8 when the responses are measured in the x-direction. Similar results were obtained for the signals sequenced from 21 to 24 when the responses are measured in the y-direction. These periodograms were calculated using the following formula (The MathWorks Inc., 2004): (1) Figure 8.
Frequency content for signals sequenced from 17 to 20 (Table 4) measured along the excitation direction.

Figure 8 shows how the peak occurs for the same value of frequency in the case of 1 and 2 mm of initial displacements, which is 4.4 Hz, while increasing the initial value of displacement (3 and 5 mm), inducing slight damage in the specimen and resulting in a lower value of the fundamental frequency (4.27 and 4.07 Hz, respectively), and hence lower stiffness value. The calculated fundamental frequencies for all the developed tests are listed in Table 5. Table 5.
Fundamental frequencies. In the cases where damage is evident, the initial behavior is reported
Axial force (ton) Direction Initial displacement (mm) Fundamental frequency (Hz)
Without SMA With SMA
10 X 1 4.4 4.93
2 4.4 4.87
3 4.27 4.87
5 4.07 4.8
Y 1 4.4 4.67
2 4.4 4.67
3 4.27 4.6
5 4.07 4.5
0 X 1 4.13 4.27
2 4 4.07
3 3.7 3.93
5 NA 3.8
Y 1 3.27 3.4
2 3.07 3.27
3 2.9 3.2
5 2.73 3.13
NA: not available, SMA: shape memory alloy.

Periodograms are also drawn for the signals sequenced from 1 to 8 (excluding no. 4 which is disregarded) in Figures 9 (signals 1–3) and 10 (signals 4–8). In general it is noticed that the correspondent values of the fundamental frequencies are lower than those of Figure 8. This is due to the decrease in the applied axial force, which decreases the total stiffness and hence the frequency corresponding to the peak. Figure 10, in particular, plots the periodograms of the signals recorded in the direction transversal to that of the excitation. The largest intensity case shows an evident progressive deterioration of the structural behavior. Figure 9.
Frequency content for signals sequenced from 1 to 3 (Table 4) measured along the excitation direction. Figure 10.
Frequency content for signals sequenced from 5 to 8 (Table 4) measured in the direction transversal to the excitation direction.

sec.title: 3.2. Tests with SMA wires
sec.p:
After performing all the planned tests for the control specimen, the four SMA wires were erected on the specimen and the same tests were performed again. Figures 11–15 show the frequency content of the signals in the direction of the excitation for all the cases in the series of signals obtained after adding SMA wires, except the ones obtained in the direction y with an extra load of 50 kN, since they would not add any specific remark to the ones discussed hereafter. The values of the calculated fundamental frequency are listed also in Table 5, from which the different behavior of the specimen with SMA wires could be noticed. Generally, the curves are moving left in each single figure, which indicates the decrease of the frequency corresponding to the peak. Moreover, a larger value in the fundamental frequency is detected than those of the control specimens. This latter evidence is mainly due to the further pre-stressing force added to the specimen by the previously strained SMA wires. Figure 11.
Frequency content for signals sequenced from 25 to 28 (Table 4). Figure 12.
Frequency content for signals sequenced from 29 to 32 (Table 4). Figure 13.
Frequency content for signals sequenced from 33 to 36 (Table 4). Figure 14.
Frequency content for signals sequenced from 41 to 44 (Table 4). Figure 15.
Frequency content for signals sequenced from 45 to 48 (Table 4).
From the obtained results the following remarks apply:

list-item.p: a comparison between Figures 8 and 11 shows a higher stiffness, a higher peak, and a lower damping after the application of the SMA wires; when the same Figure 11 is compared with Figure 12, the damage induced by the first sequence translates into lower stiffness, lower peak, and larger damping;

a comparison between Figures 9 and 14 shows an impressive reduction of the peak ordinates when the SMA wires are mounted; again the damage induced by the immediately previous sequence translates into lower stiffness and larger damping, but not into lower peak, thus showing the importance of the device replacement after a single shock.

sec.title: 4. Damping calculations
sec.p: In order to study the effect of the varied parameters on the resulting damping of the SDOF system, damping is calculated from each time-history signal for every case. The adopted method in calculating damping depends on the logarithmic decrement technique (Equation (2)) that is used to obtain the damping ratio associated with the first mode of vibration: (2) where F(t) is the acceleration at time t, A is the acceleration at time 0, ω is the circular frequency in radians, and ζ is the damping ratio.

An example of a damping calculation is shown in Figure 16, where the time history of the test 1-10-X-C is plotted, together with the exponential fitting curve. Figure 16.
Time history of 1-10-X-C with the fitted curve adopted for the damping calculation.

An alternative approach was also adopted in order to avoid misleading conclusions. The so-called half-power (–3 dB) method from Avitable (2001) suggests identifying the two pulsations ωa and ωb around the peak at ω, where the ordinates decrease at 3 dB. Then: (3)

Table 6 includes the values of damping calculated for some of the collected signals. The method of Equation (3) is reported in the last two columns, after the values obtained following Equation (2). It is seen from the table that the damping generally increases with the initial displacement, that is, the excitation intensity. In addition, for the same value of initial displacement, the damping decreases with the increase of the axial load. Table 6.
Damping values: (a) by Equation (2); (b) by Equation (3)
Axial force (ton) Direction Initial displacement (mm) Damping (%) (a) Damping (%) (b)
Without SMA With SMA Without SMA With SMA
10 X 1 1.53 1.08 1.59 1.08
2 1.8 1.18 1. 8 1.58
3 2.34 1.45 2.5 1.74
5 2.46 1.6 3.47 1.77
Y 1 1.53 1.06 1.68 1.33
2 1.8 1.24 1.92 1.44
3 2.34 1.31 2.05 1.42
5 2.46 1.39 2.69 1.86
0 X 1 1.68 1.51 2.04 1.6
2 1.73 1.37 2.75 2.19
3 1.79 1.55 3.88 2.2
5 NA 2.00 NA 4.05
Y 1 1.3 3.67 1.83 3.67
2 1.9 3.85 2.44 4.8
3 2.34 2.58 3.7 3.93
5 2.51 2.59 NA 3.83
NA: not available, SMA: shape memory alloy.
In Table 6, the cases where the two methods show discrepancies, which are marked in bold, require a further explanation as follows.

list-item.p: In the last row of Table 6 one sees that the estimate 2.51 obtained by Equation (2) is no longer achieved by the method of Equation (3). Indeed, in this case the frequency content evolves in time (i.e. there is damage, see Figure 10), which makes the latter approach unreliable.

A similar remark can be used to justify the bad estimates the approach of Equation (3) provides when the initial displacement is 3 mm (both along the x and y-directions) and there are no SMA wires added.

Again, a deep investigation of the relevant plots in Figures 8 and 12, in the direction x without SMA wires and y with SMA wires, respectively, but both with initial an displacement of 5 mm, justifies the fourth and eighth rows of Table 6.

sec.p: When focusing attention on the bottom of the table with the SMA wires mounted, two remarks arise. On one hand the approach of Equation (2) is unreliable and on the other the damping when the excitation is along the y-direction is much higher than the values estimated when the excitation is in the x-direction.

The first remark is once again justified by the progressive damage, while the second confirms the need to replace the SMA wires after they have undergone cycles of loading–unloading, if the benefit of their installation has to be preserved. Without this replacement the differences summarized in Figures 17 and 18 have to be emphasized. Figure 17.
Comparison of the time histories and of the periodograms from the signals recorded for the excitation along x (first) and y (after) without replacement of the SMA wires: (a) initial displacement 1 mm; (b) initial displacement 2 mm. Figure 18.
Comparison of the time histories and of the periodograms from the signals recorded for the excitation along x (first) and y (after) without replacement of the SMA wires: (a) initial displacement 3 mm; (b) initial displacement 5 mm.

sec.title: 5. Conclusions
sec.p: The main objective of this study is to investigate experimentally the effects of different parameters (namely, axial compression, initial displacement, and direction of application) on a SDOF masonry model before and after rehabilitation using Cu-based SMA wire devices.

In this investigation, a total of 48 free vibration tests were performed on the 1/16th scale model of the Qusun minaret at Cairo University Concrete Research Laboratory, varying the aforementioned parameters. The overall structural behavior under free vibration was recorded in two perpendicular directions to detect the actual testing conditions. Acceleration time histories were obtained by means of three accelerometers, then the acquired data were processed and the fundamental frequency and damping ratio values were calculated from the signals obtained by each test.

The results showed a significant increase of the fundamental frequencies of the SDOF in the all performed tests when the axial force had been increased. A further noticed increase in the frequency was associated with the addition of SMA wires, which proves higher stiffness imparted to the SDOF model by the SMA wires.

In general, damping ratios were increasing as the initial displacement increased, caused by the gradual increase in damage induced in the system. A decrease in damping ratios was noticed when increasing the applied axial force, as well as after providing the SMA wires. This is mainly due to the larger mass and higher stiffness gained by the extra axial load and SMA wires, respectively.

sec.title: Funding
sec.p: This work was supported by the European Commission through project WIND-CHIME and by the Pavia Athenaeum (grant FAR 2009). The re-elaboration of the signals was carried out within the European Commission project SMARTEN.

sec.title: Conflict of interest
sec.p: None declared.
